text: Last lesson, you learned that CGoL is made of cells that, collectively, make up a square grid.
However, when you place the cells down, they don't just sit around doing nothing all day.
Instead, the entire grid goes through
, or iterations, which happen to every cell at once.
During a generation, each cell changes state according a few simple rules:
If an alive cell is surrounded by two or three other alive cells, it stays alive.
If a dead cell is surrounded by exactly three alive cells, it becomes alive.
All other cells become dead. (So tragic.)
Fortunately, in this program, you won't have to simulate any patterns yourself—the computer will.
This lesson has an exercise, and in it, you'll just get to know the CGoL Simulator.
To finish the exercise, all you'll have to do is run a certain pattern to a certain point.
